ygData.subject: New paper on evolving 3D objects with CPPNs (and 3D-printing them)

Subject: New paper on evolving 3D objects with CPPNs (and 3D-printing them)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=467342474; y=J4DJ5AaFmYMeaKHESkk2O3RWV9pVcurMP8vZboNquuR1bWr-En7R

Content-type: text/plain;
	charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

Hello everyone-

Hod Lipson and I have a new publication on evolving 3D morphologies with
CPPNs, which explains the algorithm behind EndlessForms.com.

PDF:  http://goo.gl/HRXLD

Most of you will at least enjoy quickly scanning the figures to see the
evolved shapes, which are higher resolution and different than those on
EndlessForms.com.  You can also see a picture of the evolved shapes 3D
printed.

The diversity of shapes I was able to discover just playing with the system
myself for a few hours is pretty incredible, which is a testament to Ken's
CPPN encoding. Additionally, I ran tests with and without recurrence in the
CPPN genome, and with different inputs to the CPPN, and you can see the
difference those choices make in the resultant objects. For example, with
CPPN recurrence, the shapes often look more fractal. I believe (but please
correct me if I am wrong) that this is the first publication with a test of
CPPNs with and without recurrence.

FInally, I conducted target-based evolution by evolving CPPNs to match a
goal object. I'd be interested to hear if you think the goal was reached,
and how to interpret these results in light of Brian Woolley & Ken Stanley's
paper on CPPNs not being able to reach target 2D objectives.

What I like best about being able to evolve 3D objects is learning how the
CPPN search space works: mutations frequently produce very sensible
variation. For example, the two 3D printed elephants in figure one are
brothers, and are close relatives of the three elephant-looking things in
figure 4 (b2-4). It's nice to see mutations have such smooth, sensible
effects, instead of creating wildly different objects.

As always, please let me know your thoughts and questions.

Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Postdoctoral Fellow
Hod Lipson's Creative Machines Laboratory
Cornell University
jeffclune@...
www.msu.edu/~jclune



--B_3391597407_30886135
